verses.text: The words of Nehemiah, son of Hacaliah. In the month of Chislev, in the twentieth year, while I was in the citadel of Susa,
verses.comment: The book's introduction roots Nehemiah within Jewish history and the Persian Empire. The mention of 'the twentieth year' refers to King Artaxerxes I, situating the events around 445 BC. Susa was a major Persian capital, emphasizing the exile context.

verses.text: Hanani, one of my brothers, came with some men from Judah, and I asked them about the Jews who had survived the exile, and about Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Nehemiah's concern for his people reveals his compassionate leadership and devotion to Jerusalem. The exile context points to God's faithfulness across generations, foreshadowing restoration.

verses.text: They replied, 'The remnant who remain in the province and have survived the exile are in great trouble and disgrace. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates are burned with fire.'
verses.comment: The state of Jerusalem symbolizes spiritual desolation and loss. The broken walls indicate vulnerability (literal and spiritual)—Jerusalem, often a figure of God's dwelling place among His people. The report stirs Nehemiah's prophetic response to rebuild.

verses.text: When I heard these words, I sat down, wept, and mourned for days. I fasted and prayed before the God of heaven.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s reaction models deep intercessory prayer—mourning, fasting, and seeking God’s mercy reflects the biblical pattern of seeking reconciliation and restoration. Here, prayer and fasting precede action, hinting at the importance of both interior devotion and exterior works.

verses.text: I said, 'O Lord, God of heaven, great and awesome God, who keeps covenant and steadfast love with those who love Him and keep His commandments,
verses.comment: Nehemiah invokes God's covenant faithfulness, echoing earlier Old Testament prayers. Observance of commandments links love and obedience, an enduring theme later echoed in Christ’s teaching (John 14:15).

verses.text: let your ear be attentive and your eyes open, to hear the prayer of your servant, which I now pray before you day and night for your servants, the people of Israel. I confess the sins we have committed against you; I and my father's house have sinned.
verses.comment: Confession and intercession are central here. Nehemiah prays continually, demonstrating faithfulness and humility. The confession is communal, recognizing need for corporate repentance, which is deeply scriptural and emphasized in tradition. Praying for others is highlighted as a spiritual work of mercy.

verses.text: We have acted very corruptly against you, and have not kept the commandments, the statutes, and the rules which you commanded your servant Moses.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s acknowledgment of Israel’s failure to obey all of God’s law echoes the Deuteronomic cycle: blessing for obedience, curses for disobedience. This asks the reader to consider the full scope of God’s revealed law and its binding nature.

verses.text: Remember the word you commanded your servant Moses: 'If you are unfaithful, I will scatter you among the nations;
verses.comment: Here, Nehemiah appeals to God’s own covenant words, recognizing both justice and mercy. The scattering alludes to exile, consistent with God's discipline but also the possibility of restoration for repentance, a theme central to biblical salvation history.

verses.text: but if you return to me and keep my commandments and do them, though your outcasts are in the farthest parts of heaven, I will gather them and bring them to the place I have chosen, to make my name dwell there.'
verses.comment: God promises restoration based on repentance and obedience, highlighting the gathering of His people to the place of His presence—a foreshadowing of the eschatological assembly. Jerusalem as God's chosen place is both literal and symbolic of spiritual union with God.

verses.text: These are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed by your great power and by your strong hand.
verses.comment: Redemption imagery links the Exodus to present deliverance. Nehemiah identifies the people as God's—chosen, redeemed, sustained by His mighty acts, echoing themes of salvation and typological pointers to Christ’s redemptive work.

verses.text: O Lord, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant, and to the prayers of your servants who delight to honor your name. Give success to your servant today, and grant him mercy in the sight of this man.' I was cupbearer to the king.
verses.comment: Nehemiah closes with petition for favor, emphasizing intercessory prayer and service tied to his vocation as cupbearer—a trusted royal official. Here is a model of lay sanctity and active faith. The phrase 'delight to honor your name' points toward the importance of worship and reverence.
